content.title: Introduction to Real Numbers and Expressions
Variables
content.body: A variable is a letter such as $$a$$, $$b$$, $$x$$ or $$y$$, that represents a mathematical quantity

content.title: Note
content.body: The inequalities $$<$$ and $$>$$, from left to right, point to the smaller and bigger of the two quantities being compared respectively. For example, $$5 < x$$ means $$5$$ is smaller than $$x$$, and is read "$$5$$ is less than $$x$$", and $$x > 4$$ means $$x$$ is bigger than $$4$$, and is read "$$x$$ is greater than $$4$$".

content.title: Symbols for Addition, Subtraction, Multiplication and Division
Grouping Symbols
content.body: The grouping symbols most frequently used in mathematics are parentheses $$( )$$, brackets $$[ ]$$, and braces $$\{ \}$$. Grouping symbols are used for grouping numbers and organizing problems in algebra.

content.title: Exponents
content.body: An exponents is a quantity that represents the amount of times a number is multiplied with itself.

content.title: Exponent Example1
content.example: Expand and Multiply $$7^2$$

content.title: Exponent Example2
content.example: Expand and Multiply $$3^3$$

content.title: Exponent Example3
content.example: Expand and Multiply $$2^4$$

content.title: Order of Operations
content.body: Mathematicians have devised a standard order of operations for calculations involving more than one arithmetic operation.

content.title: Example 4: Order of Operations
content.example: Simplify: $$6+3*2$$

content.title: Example5: Order of Operations
content.example: Simplify: $$\dfrac{35}{7*3}$$

content.title: Example7: Order of Operations
content.example: Simplify: $$\dfrac{7+18}{3+3*4}$$

content.title: Real Numbers
content.body: Real numbers are numbers that can be found on the number line, and because real numbers have permanent place on the number line, their size can be compared.

content.title: Example 1: Real Numbers
content.example: Interpret the following problem as an integer: Adult crickets die if the temperature drops 5 degrees below 0 Fahrenheit.

content.title: Note
content.body:
On the number line:
- The origin is located at the point 0.
- Positive numbers are located on the right side of 0. - Negative numbers are located on the left side of 0.
- 0 is the only number that is neither negative or positive.
**Diagram**

content.title: Example 2:
content.example:
Grpah each number on the same number line.
a) $$\dfrac{-3}{2}$$
b) $$4.2$$

content.title: Note
content.body: The symbol  means is approximately equal to.

content.title: Example 3:
content.example:
Grpah each number on the same number line.
a) $$\sqrt{2}$$
b) $$e$$
c) $$\pi$$

content.title: Comparing Real Numbers
content.body:
The number line is extremely useful in mathematics, one such use allows to compare two numbers.
** Diagram **
When comparing two number on the number line the number to the left is always smaller than the number to the right. For example, -5 is smaller than -2 since it is set to the left of -2.

content.title: Example 4:
content.example:
Determine if each inequality is true or false.
a) $-5 < -3$$
b) $$-4 \ge \dfrac{1}{4}
c) $$-3 \ge -3$$
d) $$-5.1 < -2.5$$
e) $$-3 > 0$$

content.title: Addition and Subtraction of Real Numbers
Additive Inverse Property
content.body:
For every real number $a$, there exists a real number $-a$, such that:
$$a+(-a)=0$$ and $$(-a)+a=0$$
In other words, any number added to its opposite is zero.

content.title: Note
content.body:
To Add Real Numbers:
* If the numbers have the same sign, add their values and keep their sign.
* If the numbers have different signs, find the difference between their values and keep the sign of the largest number.

content.title: Commutative Property of Addition
content.body:
For all real numbers $$a$$ and $$b$$, $$a+b = b+a$$

In other words, changing the order of the numbers in an addition problem does not change its results, for example:
$$2+3=5$$ and
$$3+2=5$$

content.title: Associative Property of Addition
content.body:
For all real numbers $$a$$, $$b$$ and $$c$$,
$$(a+b)+c = a+(b+a)$$

In other words, changing the grouping of numbers in an addition problem does not change its result.

content.title: Note
content.body:
To Subtract Real Numbers:
* When subtracting one real number from another we re-write the subtraction as addition and add the opposite of the number being subtracted, then use the rules for addition of real numbers.
* In other words, 'subtracting a number is the same as adding its opposite'.
$$a-b = a+(-b)$$
Subtracting $$b$$, is the same as adding the opposite of $$b$$

content.title: Multiplication and Division of Real Numbers
Note
content.body:
To Multiply Real Numbers:
* When multiplying two numbers with the same sign, the answer is positive, i.e.,
Positive x Positive = Positive and
Negative x Negative = Positive

* When multiplying two numbers with opposite signs, the answer is negative, i.e.,
Positive x Negative = Negative and
Negative x Positive = Negative

content.title: Commutative Property of Multiplication
content.body:
For all real numbers $$a$$ and $$b$$,
$$a*b=b*a$$

In other words, changing the order of the numbers in a multiplication problem does not change its results, for example:
$$2*3 =3*2$$

content.title: Multiplicative Identity Property
content.body:
Let $$a$$ be any real number, then
$$a*1=a$$ and $$1*a=a$$

In other words, multiplying any number by1, does not change its value, for example:
$$5*1=5$$ and $$1*5=5$

content.title: Multiplication Property of Zero
content.body:
Let $$a$$ be any real number, then
$$a*0=0$$ and $$0*a=0$$

In other words, multiplying any number by $$0$$, results in $$0$$, for example:
$$6*0=0$$ and $$0*6=0$$

content.title: Associative Property of Addition
content.body:
For all real numbers $$a$$, $$b$$, and $$c$$,
$$(a*b)c=a(b*c)$$
In other words, changing the grouping of numbers in a multiplication problem does not change its result.

content.title: Example2:
content.example:
Use the Associative Property for Multiplication to show that:
a) $$-4((-3)(2))=(-4(-3))(2)$$
b) $$-5(6(-2))=(-5(6))(-2)$
c) $$4*6$$
d) $$-7*3$$

content.title: Using Order of Operations
content.body:
* For the following examples, we will use the order of operations with the rules for multiplying, adding, and subtracting real numbers.
* Recall, the rule for order of operations tells us to work inside the parentheses first and then simplify all numbers with exponents. After which, we multiply and divide left to right. Finally we add and subtract left to right.

content.title: Division of Real Numbers
content.body:
For all real numbers $$a$$ and $$b$$, where $$b=0$$, then:
$$\dfrac{a}{b}=a\dfrac{1}{b}$$

content.title: Note
content.body:
To Divide Real Numbers:
* When dividing two numbers with the same sign, the answer is positive, i.e.,
Positive / Positive = Positive and
Negative / Negative = Positive

* When dividing two numbers with opposite signs, the answer is negative, i.e.,
Positive / Negative = Negative and
Negative / Positive = Negative

content.title: Dividing with Zero
content.body:
For any real number $$a$$, where $$a\neq0$$, then it alwaystrue that:

$$0$$ divided by $$a$$ equals $$0$$
$$\dfrac{0}{a}=0$$

$$a$$ divided by $$0$$ is $$undefined$$
$$\dfrac{a}{0}=undefined$$

content.title: Example5:
content.example:
We use the order of operations rule to simplify the following expressions
a) $$\dfrac{-3(-4)}{2(-2)}$$
b) $$\dfrac{-5+(-7)}{2}')}
c) $$\dfrac{-10-10}{-7-3}$$
d) $$\dfrac{3(-2)+4}{14}$$
e) $$\dfrac{4(-3)+5(-2)}{3(2)-4(1)}$$
f) $$\dfrac{4^2-2^2}{-4+2}$$
Tip: Parentheses are understood to be around the numerator and the denominator.

content.title: Terms
content.body: A Term is either a single number or variable, or numbers and variables multiplied or divided together.

content.title: Algebraic Expressions
content.body: An Algebraic Expression is a group of terms separated by addition or subtraction signs

content.title: Example 1
content.example:
Find the number of terms in each expression
a) $$5m+3$$
b) $$\dfrac{p}{q}$$

content.title: Exponents
content.body:
An expression written in the form
$$\dfrac{x}{n}
where $$x$$ is any real number called the base and $$n$$ is an integer called the exponent or power.

content.title: Example 3
content.example:
Rewrite each expression using exponents
a) $$(5)(5)(-4)(-4)(-4)$$ b) $$-7*7*7$$
c) $$-4*x*x$$ d) $$-8n*n*m*m*m*m$$

content.title: To Evaluate an Algebraic Expression
content.body: * We evaluate algebraic expressions by substituting a number for each variable and perform the arithmetic operations.

content.title: Example
content.example:
Evaluate each algebraic expression.
a) $$32-w$$, if $$w=-10$$
b) $$-7xy$$, if $$x=-2$$ and $$y=3$$
c) $$7+f$$, if $$f=-13$$
d) $$-5ab$$, if $$a=-1$$ and $$b=6$$

content.title: Like Terms
content.body:
* Like terms are terms that have the same variable part.
* Unlike terms are terms that do not have the same variable part.
NoteIn any term, the number in front of the variable is called the coefficient. For example:
- the coefficient of $$2x$$ is $$2$$.
- the coefficient of $$-7n$$ is $$-7$$.
- the coefficient of $$x$$ is $$1$$.

content.title: Example 1
content.example:
Determine whether the terms in each algebraic expression are 'like terms' or 'unlike terms'.
a) $$w+7w$$
b) $$2b-8$$
c) $$4a^2c-8ac^2
d) $$12f-5f+f$$

content.title: The Distributive Property
content.body:
For all real numbers $$a$$, $$b$$, and $$c$$,
$$a(b+c)=ab+ac$$ and
$$a(b-c)=ab-ac$$
In other words, multiplication distributes over addition and subtraction.

content.title: Example 2
content.example:
Use the Distributive Property
a) $$(-15)(2x+w)$$
b) $$(8-2)y$$
c) $$5(h+7n)

content.title: Combining Like Terms
content.body: Combining Like Terms is a mathematical process used to simplify an expression by adding or subtracting the like terms.

content.title: Equation
content.body: An equation is a mathematical statement that shows two expressions or quantities are equal.

content.title: Solutions to an Equation
content.body: A solution to an equation is a value for a variable that makes an equation true.

content.title: Example 1
content.example:
a) Is $$3$$ a solution of the equation $$5z-3=6+2z$$ ?
b) Determine wheather $$-2$$ os a solution of the equation $$7a+3=4(a-3)$$?

content.title: Equivalent Equations
content.body: Two or more equations with the same solution are said to be Equivalent Equations.

content.title: Addition Property of Equality
content.body:
For all real numbers $$a$$, $$b$$, and $$c$$, if:
$$a=b$$, then $$a+c=b+c$$
In other words, adding the same quantity to each side of an equation results in an equivalent equation.

content.title: Example 2
content.example:
a) Solve the equation $$x-18=-6$$ for $$x$$. ?
b) Solve the equation $$-11=b+7$$ $$b$$?

content.title: Multiplication Property of Equality
content.body:
For all real numbers $$a$$, $$b$$ and $$c$$, if:
$$a=b$$, then $$ac=bc$$
In other words, multiplying each side of an equation by the same (non zero) quantity results in an equivalent equation.

content.title: Example 1
content.example:
a) Solve the equation $$-w=19$$ for $$w$$
b) Solve the equation $$9a=45$$ for $$a$$
c) Solve the equation $$\dfrac{c}{3}=12$$ for $$c$$
d) Solve the equation $$\dfrac{3n}{5}=6$$ for $$c$$
e) Solve the equation $$\dfrac{2}{5}m= \dfrac{6}{15}$$ for $$c$$.

content.title: Using the Addition and Multiplication Property to Solve Linear Equations.
content.body:
A linear equation in one variable is any equation that can be put in the form
$$ax+b=c$$
where $$a$$, $$b$$, and $$c$$, are real numbers and a is not zero.

content.title: Using the Addition and Multiplication Property to Solve Linear Equations.
Example 1
content.example:
a) Solve the equation $$15=-6-7a$$ for $$a$$
b) Solve the equation $$7=\dfrac{x}{4}+1$$ for $$x$$.

content.title: Using Combining Like Terms to Solve Linear Equations
content.body: Before we can use the addition and multiplication properties of equality to solve linear equations we must first combine all like terms.

content.title: Combining Like Terms to Solve Linear Equations
Example 2
content.example:
a) Solve the equation $$3y-8y=20$$ for $$y$$
b) Solve the equation $$7-r-r=-1$$ for $$r$$
c) Solve the equation $$4x-9=-x-10$$ for $$x$$
d) Solve the equation $$\dfrac{1}{5}z-\dfrac{1}{10}z=\dfrac{3}{5}$$ for $$z$$.

content.title: Using the Distributive Property to Solve Linear Equations
content.body: Before we can use the addition and multiplication properties of equality to solve linear equations we must first combine all like terms.

content.title: Distributive Property to Solve Linear Equations
Example 3
content.example:
a) Solve the equation $$-4(w+5)$$ for $$w$$
b) Solve the equation $$4(r-3)-3(r-4)$$ for $$r$$
c) Solve the equation $$3[4x-(x-2)]=6(x-3)$$ for $$x$$.

content.title: Using the Addition and Multiplication Properties of Equality to Solve Literal Equations
content.body: A literal equation or formula is an equation that contains more than one variable.

content.title: Addition and Multiplication Properties of Equality to Solve Literal Equations
Example 1
content.example:
a) Solve the equation $$a+10=b$$ for $$a$$
b) Solve the equation $$3w-z=9$$ for $$w$$
c) Solve the equation $$V=Iwh$$ for $$h$$
d) Solve the equation $$ax+by=c$$ for $$y$$
e) Solve the equation $$3x+5y=20$$ for $$y$$.

content.title: Using the Distributive Property to Solve Literal Equations
content.body: If an equation contains parentheses, then the use of the distributive property is required. The distributive properly is used to remove parentheses from expressions that contains variables.

content.title: Using the Distributive Property to Solve Literal Equations
Example 1
content.example:
a) Solve the equation $$n=r(a+b)$$ for $$r$$
b) Solve the equation $$z=4(x-3y)$$ for $$y$$
c) Solve the equation $$S=a+(n-1)d$$ for $$n$$.

content.title: Linear Inequality
content.body:
A linear inequality in one variable is two or more terms or expressions separated by one or more of the following inequalities:
$$<$$, $$>$$, $$ \le $$, $$ \ge $$ or $$\ne$$.
For Example: $$x>3$$, $$9 \le a-7$$ and $$z\ne8$$.

content.title: Graphing Inequalities and their Solutions
content.body: We can graph an inequality by representing all of its solutions on a number line.

content.title: Example 1
content.example:
Graph the following inequalities.
a) $$y>1$$
b) $$-2 \ge b$$

content.title: Addition Property for Inequalities
content.body:
For all real numbers $$a$$, $$b$$, and $$c$$, if:
* $$a * $$a * $$a>b$$, then $$a+c>b+c$$
* $$a>b$$, then $$a-c>b-c$$

In other words, adding or subtracting the same value to an inequality will not change the inequality or it's solution set. In other words, adding or subtracting the same value to an inequality will not change the inequality or it's solution set.In other words, adding or subtracting the same value to an inequality will not change the inequality or it's solution set.In other words, adding or subtracting the same value to an inequality will not change the inequality or it's solution set.

Note: The Property hold for $$ \le $$ and \ge as well.

content.title: Example 2
content.example:
Solve and graph the following inequalities
a) $$a+6>1$$
b) $$9 \le m+11$$

content.title: Multiplication Property for Inequalities
content.body:
For all real numbers $$a$$, $$b$$, and $$c$$, if:
When $$c$$ is positive
* $$a * $$abc$$
When $$c$$ is negative
* $$abc$$
* $$a>b$$, then $$ac>bc$$

In other words, adding or subtracting the same value to an inequality will not change the inequality or it's solution set. In other words, adding or subtracting the same value to an inequality will not change the inequality or it's solution set.In other words, adding or subtracting the same value to an inequality will not change the inequality or it's solution set.In other words, adding or subtracting the same value to an inequality will not change the inequality or it's solution set.

Note: The Property hold for $$ \le $$ and \ge as well.
In other words, multiplying or dividing both sides of an inequality by a positive number will not change the inequality or its solution set but when we multiply or divide an inequality by a negative number we must reverse the direction of the inequality symbol so that we we do not change the inequality or its solution set. Note The property Hold for $$\l$$ and $$ \ge $$ as well.

content.title: Example 3
content.example:
Solve and graph the following inequalities
a) $$3n<12$$
b) $$-6w \le 54$$
c) $$\dfrac{T}{3}>5$$
d) $$-\dfrac{r}{2} \ge 6$$

content.title: Using Combining Like Terms to Solve Linear Inequalities
content.body: When using the addition and multiplication properties of inequalities to solve linear inequalities we may also have to combine all like terms.

content.title: Combining Like Terms to Solve Linear Inequalities
Example 4
content.example:
Solve and graph the following inequalities
a) $$7x-7<6x+3$$
b) $$6x-9x \ge -12$$
c) $$10x+4 \ge 4x-2$$
d) $$4x-3>8x+17$$

content.title: Using The Distributive Property to Solve Linear Inequalities
content.body: Before using the addition and multiplication properties of inequalities and Combining Like Terms to solve linear inequalities we may also have to use The Distributive Property.

content.title: The Distributive Property to Solve Linear Inequalities
Example 5
content.example:
Solve and graph the following inequalities
a) $$704x \le 15(x+1)$$
b) $$-8(2-x) \le 5(x-2)$$
